;历届政府未能掌握和应对中国构成的威胁的规模议会间谍机构监管机构表示，它警告说，中国情报机构“大量且积极地”针对英国。

;

;情报与安全委员会 (ISC) 发布的一份内容广泛的新报告对英国提出了批评政府对中国构成的威胁的反应，质疑经济利益和安全考虑之间的权衡。

;

;这也引发了人们对中国在英国大学的影响力以及该国成为“永久且重要的参与者”的意图的担忧”在民用核能行业。

;

;议员们表示，这份 200 页的报告应该给部长们敲响“警钟”，因为 ISC 警告称，中国针对工业和技术的攻击可能会构成“生死存亡”。报告发现，英国“在间谍活动和干涉方面仍然对中国有重大兴趣”，使该国“略低于中国的首要目标”。

;

;声明称：“中国的国家情报机构——几乎可以肯定是世界上最大的国家情报机构，拥有数十万民事情报官员……大量而积极地针对英国及其利益，这对我们的机构来说是一个挑战。” ”

;

;这个由九名成员组成的委员会由保守党议员朱利安·刘易斯爵士 (Sir Julian Lewis) 担任主席，负责审查英国情报机构的工作，包括军情五处 (MI5)、军情六处 (MI6) 和政府通讯总部 (GCHQ)。

;

;其报告由英国政府查看首相发布前，最新报告发布之际西方与崛起的亚洲强国之间持续紧张。

;

;一名女子起诉英国军情五处

;< p>;政府将中国日益增长的影响力描述为“划时代的挑战”，但议员们敦促部长和官员更深入地考虑其构成的安全威胁类型。

;

;ISC 报告称，英国在解决委员会成员所称的中国“举全国之力”进行海外间谍活动和干涉的问题时，资源“完全不足”。

;

;它警告说存在短视思维和缺乏能力的危险。应对中国构成的威胁的长期规划。

;

;“英国现在正在追赶，整个政府都在努力了解和应对来自中国的威胁，”报告称。

;

;“英国目前采取的短期主义做法严重阻碍了其发展。”

;

;军情五处局长肯·麦卡勒姆在向国会议员提供的证据中表示：“中国的崛起绝对给西方联盟的未来提出了巨大的问题......

;

;“对于未来几十年全球力量平衡的具体表现，我们没有人能够给出自信的长期答案，但我们所有人都清楚，我认为这是我们未来十年面临的主要情报挑战。”

;

;报告中特别关注中国对英国大学的影响力。这并不是第一次对中国控制高等教育表示焦虑。

;

;里希·苏纳克(Rishi Sunak)在去年的保守党党魁竞选中承诺，将关闭英国各地的 30 所中国政府资助的孔子学院。报告称，英国“学术机构为中国在英国取得政治影响力和经济优势提供了丰富的土壤”。

;

;报告补充道：“为了控制辩论的叙述，中国通过利用费用和资金对机构施加影响，通过利诱和恐吓对英国学者个人施加影响，通过监视和控制对中国学生施加影响，通过胁迫对智库施加影响。”

;< p>;但议员们表示，政府对学术界就此事提出的警告“兴趣不大”。

;

;英国将从敏感地点移除中国制造的监控设备

;

;报告还指出对中国在民用核能领域发挥的作用表示担忧。

;

;中国广核集团去年退出了萨福克塞兹韦尔 C 核电站项目，但议员们表示，部长们对未来项目仍存在严重疑问.

;

;报告称，“政府如果认为允许中国公司对英国民用核能和能源行业施加影响并不意味着将控制权拱手让给中国共产党，那就太天真了。”

;

;“因此，政府仍然在细粒度地考虑中国参与英国关键的国家基础设施是不可接受的。

;

;“我们对中国参与间谍活动的动机和机会感到严重担忧在英国民用核部门规定。虽然我们认识到颠覆的威胁不太可能，但影响力的威胁却非常真实。”

;

;政府必须对该报告做出回应，并于周四向议会提交该文件的副本。

;

;6 月，ISC 表示正在“寻求答案”，以延迟获得唐宁街对该报告的批准。

;

;苏纳克先生确实在三份和一份报告中立即做出了回应。半页的声明，其中他列出了为改善英国对中国的反应而采取的措施。

;

;首相还表示，ISC 调查于 2019 年开始，并于 2020 年收集了大部分证据，“早于2021 年综合审查和 2023 年综合审查更新”。

;

;“这些都是全面的国家安全和国际政策审查，大大加强了我们对中国的立场”，他说。 “政府已经采取了符合委员会许多建议的行动”。

;

;但委员会成员对这一声明进行了反击，工党的凯文·琼斯 (Kevan Jones) 称其“软弱”，并批评总理未能首先与 ISC 分享。

;

;“如果这是政府的回应，并且不知何故报告已经过时，我会提出比这更好的论据。”

;

;朱利安爵士还在新闻发布会上告诉记者：“我一直煞费苦心地指出，在取证方面我们必须有一个截止点。

;

;“这并不意味着说我们没有持续进行对话并接收季度报告，例如来自涵盖所有这些事务的所有情报机构的季度报告。”

;

;在报告的其他地方，议员们敦促部长们在国家安全问题上采取进一步措施立法并颁布反国家威胁法案。

;

;ISC 还呼吁内阁办公室对情报机构是否达到应对中国面临的挑战的目标进行审查。

;< p>;“我认为最令人震惊的是这在10年前就已经知道了？是的，”琼斯说。

;

;6 月份出口量也降至六个月低点。< /p>;

;“随着全球商品需求低迷继续影响出口，我们认为出口在年底触底之前将进一步下降，”凯投宏观分析师表示。

;< p>;上半年，中国出口较2022年同期下降3.2%。

;

;

;

;

;“这一下降主要是由于全球大宗商品价格下跌所致。供应冲击逐渐消失。事实上，经季节性调整后，我们估计 6 月份进口量环比增长 4%，高于 5 月份的 0.3%，”牛津经济研究院高级经济学家劳埃德·陈 (Lloyd Chan) 表示。

;

;

;进口量在 5 月份达到 23 个月高位后，6 月份变化不大，分析师预计未来几个月进口量将会回升。

;< p>;上半年，中国进口同比下降6.7%。

;

;

;

;对中国主要贸易伙伴的出口均出现两位数下降

;

;中国最大贸易伙伴东南亚国家联盟的出口量同比下降16.86%。

;

;与此同时，对欧盟的出口也出现下降同比下降12.92%，而对美国的出口连续第11个月下降，其中6月下降23.73%，为11月以来的最大降幅。

;

;相比之下，对俄罗斯的出口与去年同月相比，6 月份增长了 90.93%。

;

;牛津经济研究院的 Chan 表示，主要贸易伙伴的出口普遍下降。

;

;< /h3>;

;由于出口降幅超过进口降幅，6月份中国贸易顺差总额从去年同期的974亿美元收窄至706.2亿美元。 5月份贸易顺差为658亿美元。

;

;但牛津经济研究院的陈表示，第二季度货物贸易余额仍从前三个月的2034亿美元扩大至2266亿美元

;

;

;

;凯投宏观分析师预计，出口将进一步下降，然后在年底触底，全球商品需求低迷继续影响出货量。

;

;“但好消息是，外国需求下降最严重的时期可能已经过去了。发达经济体仍面临衰退，但衰退可能较为温和，对中国出口的影响有限。”他们表示。

;

;“与此同时，绿色技术的出货量，包括中国制造的电动汽车、电池牛津经济研究院的陈指出，中国官方制造业采购经理人指数的出口订单分项指数下滑至五个月6 月份为 46.4 的低点。

;

;“由于主要央行希望进一步收紧货币政策，我们对下半年中国出口保持谨慎展望。需求疲弱的迹象已经出现，大宗商品价格下跌和韩国新出口订单大幅下降就表明了这一点。”他补充道。

;

;但凯投宏观分析师补充道，进口量可能会在 2020 年回升。未来几个月，财政刺激措施预计将在今年晚些时候增加基础设施支出并支持大宗商品进口。

;

;国际旅行预计也将继续复苏，从而提高燃料进口进一步增加的潜力，他们补充道.

;

;“进口疲软和通货紧缩风险上升表明增长势头放缓，从而有理由采取更多政策刺激措施来支持经济复苏，”陈说。

;

;Pregnant women who contract Covid-19 face an increased risk of complications such as preterm birth and in the worst case, a stillborn child, a joint study by researchers at Hong Kong universities has found.

;

;The SARS-CoV-2 virus, which causes Covid-19, significantly disrupted the development of the placenta in pregnant women, especially those in their third trimester, academics from the University of Science and Technology (HKUST) and Chinese University (CUHK) said on Thursday.

;

;“The placenta is a very vascular organ and the formation of the placenta requires new blood vessels to support the growth of the fetus,” said Dr Liona Poon Chiu-yee, head of the obstetrics and gynaecology department at CUHK's faculty of medicine.

;

;“Abnormal blood vessel formation within the placenta will restrict the growth of the fetus as the placenta cannot provide sufficient nutrition and oxygen.”

;

;Blood test by Hong Kong researchers can detect nasopharyngeal cancer risk

;

;Irregular development of the placenta might lead to pre-eclampsia, a form of hypertension in pregnant women, and gestational diabetes.

;

;Pre-eclampsia can cause serious complications such as stroke and premature births and affects around three to five pregnant women in every 100 in Hong Kong.

;

;Insufficient nutrients and oxygen delivered by the placenta might result in the fetus being a low-weight, preterm birth and in the worst case, cause stillbirth.

;

;The team from the two universities collected samples from the placenta and uterus wall of 14 pregnant women in Hong Kong over two years, including seven infected with Covid-19 in their third trimester.

;

;Of the seven, five showed Covid-19 symptoms. The infected women, aged between 27 to 42, were on average 35.9 weeks into their pregnancy when diagnosed with the coronavirus.

;

;While Covid-19 does not transmit directly from the mother to the fetus, the team found that the viral infection triggered a significant increase in the woman's immune response, which affected her gene activity.

;

;The team also found that infected mothers-to-be had more than 70 per cent fewer pregnancy-specific glycoprotein (PSG) genes in their placenta compared with uninfected women.

;

;“Covid-19 patients have a significantly lower level of PSG genes in their placenta. PSG genes are known to stop blood clots and control the immune response of the mother, which can impact fetus health,” said Danny Leung Chi-yeu, director of the Centre for Epigenomics Research at HKUST.

;

;The research supports the finding of a previous study of more than 13,000 pregnant women by George Washington University in the United States, which found that those infected with SARS-CoV-2 faced a seven times increase in the risk of death, while their newborns faced a higher risk of preterm birth and low birthweight.

;

;70 per cent of Hong Kong Covid victims have long-term after-effects, survey finds

;

;Poon also warned mothers-to-be against delaying their Covid-19 jabs and stressed the importance of virus prevention.

;

;“The reluctance of getting vaccinated before pregnancy is a major issue. A lot of women are still worried about the effects of vaccination on their ability to get pregnant but that has not been proven,” she said.

;

;Poon added that pregnant women who got vaccinated also passed on antibodies to their newborn through the umbilical cord, protecting them from Covid-19.

;

;“If you don't get vaccinated during pregnancy, your newborn will not be protected from Covid during the first six months because they are not going to get vaccinated immediately after birth.”

;

;Long Covid could be longer – and worse – than we thought, study finds

;

;Poon also urged expectant mothers to actively test themselves to get timely treatment even as society exited the pandemic.

;

;“Even in these cases where they didn't have a severe form of Covid-19, we already saw such severe impact in the maternal-fetal interface, let alone a severe Covid-19 case,” she said.

;

;“Upon detecting the infection, we need to provide additional pregnancy care, including more frequent monitoring through ultrasound and cardiotocography to check the infant's heart rate.”

; Thu, 13 Jul 2023 22:50:04 +0800 Germany’s new China strategy marks break with past as new emphasis placed on de-riskinghttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3227614/germanys-new-china-strategy-marks-break-past-new-emphasis-placed-de-risking?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.13 22:27;
;;

;Germany launched a sweeping blueprint for overhauling its relationship with China on Thursday, confirming a landmark shift in how it views its biggest trading partner.

;

;The country's new China strategy had been delayed for months after a process that was beset by infighting among the three-party coalition.

;

;But its publication made clear that while Berlin wishes to maintain a close and wide-ranging dialogue with Beijing on issues of mutual interest, a new approach is required towards a state that is changing rapidly and poses innumerable and serious risks to Germany's interests.

;

;“China has changed. As a result of this and China's political decisions, we need to change our approach to China,” read the document, seen as a flagship foreign policy issue for Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock.

;

;The 40-page document laid out a cold and scathing view of today's China and its intentions, marking a break from an era in which bilateral ties and trade blossomed under former chancellor Angela Merkel.

;

;“The strategy confirms what the sparrows have been whistling from the rooftops for a long time: continuing chancellor Merkel's China policy by other means is not an option for Germany in light of the changing reality,” said Reinhard Buetikofer, an influential German member of the European Parliament.

;

;Chinese Premier visits Germany to solidify ties amid 'chaos and changes'

;

;While the paper makes broad policy recommendations, it is best viewed as a way to chart future relations.

;

;“Anyone who listens to China knows that it will assertively shape the course of this century. With the China strategy we set up a compass to guide our relations,” Baerbock tweeted.

;

;On the economic front, the government has thrown its support behind the European Union's de-risking policy but made clear it is not interested in decoupling.

;

;In a marker of how much the German view on China has changed, the strategy acknowledged that the EU's investment deal with China, pushed through by Merkel in the last days of 2020, was “not possible at the present time”.

;

;“It is not our intention to impede China's economic progress and development. At the same time, de-risking is urgently needed. However, we are not pursuing a decoupling of our economies,” the document said.

;

;Germany made clear that its China policy would align with broader EU goals, after years in which it has been accused of pursuing its own commercial interests at the expense of European unity.

;

;Amid heated debate about what European de-risking will look like, the German version promotes building up Europe's own industrial base and seeking trade deals with alternative partners. Germany is also expected to seek ways to protect its own competitive advantages.

;

;In future, government export credit guarantees for deals in China will be predicated on whether they help fuel domestic repression, the potential for technology transfer to Chinese partners and whether they deepen existing imbalances.

;

;With this point in mind, Germany offered tentative support for the most controversial element of the EU's plan – the screening of outbound investments into China.

;

;“We have a common interest in preventing the narrow set of technological advances that are assessed to be core to enhancing the military and intelligence capabilities of actors who may use these capabilities to undermine international peace and security,” read the report.

;

;Companies trading with China will be expected to carry out their own de-risking, and the report warned that the government will not bail out those that fail to address “concentration risks … in the event of a geopolitical crisis”.

;

;China's Li Qiang warns of 'de-risking' risks during Germany, France visits

;

;The strategy was cautiously welcomed by German businesses.

;

;“Derisking but not decoupling – this strategy is correct. It addresses geopolitical risks, but at the same time emphasises Germany's interest in substantial economic relations and cooperation with China to tackle global challenges,” said Siegfried Russwurm, President of the Federation of German Industries.

;

;Berlin made clear that it was acting because of changes in Beijing's economic practices, accusing it of reducing its own economic reliance on other countries while “making international production chains more dependent on China”.

;

;In a harbinger of what the reaction from Beijing will be, China's top foreign ministry official for Europe, Wang Lutong, tweeted that “Germany now faces many challenges and it's important to address the root causes. But one thing is for sure: none of the problems are caused by China”.

;

;On the security front, Germany made clear that China's cosy ties with Russia would affect relations, and warned Beijing against providing arms to support the invasion of Ukraine.

;

;“China's relationship with Russia, in particular since Russia's war of aggression against Ukraine, is an immediate security concern for Germany,” the strategy read, adding that arms deliveries would “have an immediate impact on relations between the EU and China and on our bilateral ties”.

;

;It threw its support behind Taiwanese civil society's involvement at the United Nations, and made clear that Berlin saw direct risks in the Taiwan Strait.

;

;“Germany is working for de-escalation. The status quo in the Taiwan Strait may only be changed by peaceful means and mutual consent. Military escalation would also affect German and European interests,” it read.

;

;It accused China of “eroding Hong Kong's autonomy” and committing “grave violations of human rights” in Tibet and Xinjiang.

;

;“We cannot close our eyes to the changes in China's policies; they affect the quality of our relations,” it read.

;

;Berlin plans to monitor the activities of Confucius Institutes closely after a string of accusations that they have been used to interfere in the country's academic, social and political life.

;

;German organisations were warned to make sure their partnerships with the institutes uphold “the principle of the freedom of science, research and academic teaching”, while any government-funded activities must be “open to public inspection”.

;

;Berlin also said it would also be monitoring Beijing's “transnational repression”, including the role of overseas police stations. China has denied accusations by Germany and other Western countries that it has operated such stations illegally.

;

;German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, who has reportedly clashed with Baerbock over China policy, posted on Twitter that the goal of the new strategy was “not to disconnect us”.

;

;“However, we want to avoid critical dependencies in the future. With the China strategy, we are responding to a China that is changing and taking a more offensive stance. For us, the following applies: China is and will remain a partner, competitor and systemic rival.”

;“The recent commendations indicate Beijing's emphasis on strategic deterrence, with its nuclear capability needing to be enhanced in both quality and quantity.”

;The Sanya base plays host to the country's most advanced nuclear-armed submarines, the Type 094A, or Jin-class, which can fire JL-3 ballistic missiles that have a range of 10,000km and are capable of striking the continental United States.

;China increased its number of nuclear warheads from 350 to 410 last year, according to a report published by the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute think tank last month.

;

;Beijing-based naval analyst Li Jie said submarine-launched missiles are a key component of the country's nuclear deterrent as it seeks to counter US activities in the disputed South China Sea and around Taiwan.

;

;“China has achieved significant achievements in upgrading its nuclear triad capability in recent years, but only the submarine-based missiles offer the strongest deterrence by escaping detection from US satellites,” Li said.

;

;The nuclear triad consists of ground-based intercontinental ballistic missiles as well as weapons that can be launched from the sea or the air.

;

;“The sub-launched JL-3 missile ensures Beijing has a credible second-strike capability once other countries attempt to attack China with a nuclear bomb,” Li said.

;“The honour to the Sanya-based submarine troop also shows Beijing has made every effort to enhance its nuclear deterrence to counter Washington's possible military intervention in the event of a conflict over Taiwan.”
